title: How to Heal Scabs on Your Face

steps.title: Wash the scabs on your face with clean, warm water and a gentle cleanser.
steps.content: Wash the scabs on your face with clean, warm water and a gentle cleanser. Use a light, circular motion to cleanse your skin, then rinse your face off thoroughly with warm water. Washing your face can boost your skin’s moisture and promote healing. It can also clear away bacteria and dirt that may cause infections. [1] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Avoid washing any skin that is turning white, which means it’s oversaturated. This can cause skin tissue to break, lead to infection, and increase healing time. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Use a soft, clean towel to gently pat your face dry.
steps.content: Use a soft, clean towel to gently pat your face dry. Use an even lighter touch on your scabs. [3] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Taking care when drying your face and leaving your scabs slightly damp can prevent them from ripping off and promote healing.

steps.title: Dab a thin layer of petroleum jelly or a similar product on your wound.
steps.content: Dab a thin layer of petroleum jelly or a similar product on your wound. Do this each time you wash your face or change your dressing. Keeping the scab moist will promote healing and potentially prevent scarring. [4] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source You don’t need to use an antibiotic ointment so long as you keep the wound clean.

steps.title: Place a sterile non-stick gauze dressing or non-adhesive bandage over the scab.
steps.content: Place a sterile non-stick gauze dressing or non-adhesive bandage over the scab. [5] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Keeping your scabs covered helps them retain moisture, which helps them heal. A bandage can also minimize the risk of your scabs getting infected. [6] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Change the dressings daily or if they are dirty, wet, or damaged. [7] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Touching, picking at, and scratching your face can dislodge the scabs.
steps.content: Touching, picking at, and scratching your face can dislodge the scabs. It can also interfere with healing and cause scarring, especially if your scabs come off. [8] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Once your wound heals, apply sunscreen daily to minimize scarring. [9] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Check your face and scabs every day to see if they’re healing well.
steps.content: Check your face and scabs every day to see if they’re healing well. Look for symptoms of possible infection of your scabs or surrounding skin. Seek immediate medical attention if you have: [10] X Research source Redness Pain Swelling Warmth Discharge and/or foul odor

steps.title: Let them know what home care measures you’ve tried and how they’ve helped.
steps.content: Let them know what home care measures you’ve tried and how they’ve helped. Your doctor can figure out why your scabs may not be healing properly. They can also treat your scabs to help heal them and the surrounding skin.
